text: "Hello Musa" is a ........... opening for a friendly letter, but it is inappropriate for a formal letter
explanation: The underlined word in the sentence is “inappropriate,” which means not suitable or proper. The word that is most nearly opposite in meaning to “inappropriate” and correctly fills the gap is “suitable.”

text: We blamed Obi for breaking the door, but when Ade confessed that he did it, Obi was...........
explanation: In this context, "exonerated" means that Obi was cleared of blame after Ade confessed, which is the opposite of being blamed.

text: Parking on this street is ........on weekdays, but permitted at weekends.
explanation: The word "prohibited" is the opposite of "permitted." It means that parking is not allowed on weekdays.

text: The children expected to be praised for putting out the fire, but they were..........for taking such a risk.
explanation: In this sentence, "rebuked" means to be criticised or reprimanded, which is the opposite of being praised. Therefore, the most appropriate word to fill the gap is "rebuked."

text: They had to ........ the old buildings to construct the five-star hotel.
explanation: In the sentence, "demolish" means to destroy. So the opposite of "construct" would be to demolish.

text: If we can commence the meeting on time, we should be able to ............ by 4.00 p.m.
explanation: "Commence" means to begin and the opposite of beginning is "adjourn" which means to end or suspend a meeting.

text: A child got stuck trying to squeeze through an iron fence, but some adults managed to ......... him.
explanation: "Extricate" means to free someone from a difficult or entangled situation, which is the opposite of "stuck."

text: They ended the discussion on amicable terms though they were........to each other at the beginning.
explanation: "Hostile" is the opposite of "amicable" (friendly or peaceful). It means that the two parties were unfriendly or antagonistic at the beginning of the discussion.

text: The class prefect's ............of the quarrel is different from yours.
explanation: "Account" is a detailed description or explanation of an event.

text: I refused to ...........my statement because it was true.
explanation: "Retract" means to withdraw or take back a statement.

text: But for the timely.........of the police, there would have been a riot.
explanation: "Intervention" is becoming involved in a situation to prevent it from escalating.

text: The boys were about to trade blows, but I managed to hold one of them back while my friend..............the other
explanation: To restrain means to hold back or prevent someone from doing something.

text: We are waiting to hear the weather.......for tomorrow.
explanation: "Forecast" is a prediction or estimate of future weather conditions.

text: I will tell you the secret if you promise not to .......it.
explanation: "Divulge" means to reveal or disclose information, especially something meant to be kept secret.

text: The hilltop was a hundred meters above sea level and from that......the whole town could be seen beautifully laid out.
explanation: "Altitude" refers to the height above sea level. The hilltop is described as being above sea level.

text: Until now, Etim has always started the fights, but this time Adamu is clearly the ..........
explanation: An "aggressor" is someone who initiates or starts a conflict or fight.

text: If found guilty, a person may appeal to a higher court in the hope that it will......the verdict.
explanation: In legal contexts, "reverse" means to overturn or change a decision or verdict.

text: The visit of the patron of the club ...... the morale of the players.
explanation: The word "boosted" means to improve or increase. It is commonly used in English along with the word "morale."

text: Although Aliyu was acquitted by the court for want of evidence, the police still kept a tab on him. This means that they

options.B: set a trap to catch him again
options.C: attached a tag to his clothes

explanation: "Kept a tab on him" means that the police continued to monitor or watch him closely, even though he was acquitted due to lack of evidence.

text: When it came to the question of an increase in allowances, the striking workers spoke with one voice. This means that the workers

options.B: appointed one of them as their spokesman
options.C: repeated their demand in a chorus

explanation: The phrase "spoke with one voice" means that the workers were in complete agreement or had a unified stance on the issue of an increase in allowances.

text: The restaurant owner offered Olu a drink on the house. This means that

options.A: the drink was taken to Olu's house
options.B: Olu was invited to the owner's house
options.C: the drink was free of charge
options.D: Olu was served inside the restaurant

explanation: The phrase "on the house" means that the drink was provided for free by the restaurant owner probably as a gesture of goodwill or to encourage customer satisfaction.

text: When the Choir Master introduced Jane as a brilliant singer, everyone knew that he was speaking with his tongue in his cheek. This means that he

options.A: was ignorant of the quality of Jane's singing
options.B: did not intend to be taken seriously
options.D: wanted to deceive everyone but failed

explanation: The phrase "speaking with his tongue in his cheek" means that the speaker was not being serious and likely meant the statement humorously or ironically. In this case, the Choir Master did not intend to be taken seriously when he introduced Jane as a brilliant singer.

text: When the accountant made those remarks he knew that he was putting his job on the line. This means that the accountant was

options.C: urging people to take his profession

explanation: The phrase "putting his job on the line" means that the accountant was taking a risk that could result in him losing his job.

text: The newly acquired air-bus plane is a white elephant. This means that the plane is

options.D: the biggest plane on the fleet

explanation: A "white elephant" is something that is expensive to maintain but not particularly useful or valuable. The phrase is often used to describe something that was acquired at a high cost but does not provide significant benefits.

text: Despite the measures taken by the government, the economy of the country is still in the doldrums. This means that

options.B: the government is tackling the problem vigorously
options.C: the economic problems are widely known
options.D: the economy is not making any progress

explanation: "The economy is still in the doldrums" means that the economy is in a state of stagnation or inactivity i.e. not making any progress despite efforts to improve it.

text: The new teacher urged the lazy students to turn over a new leaf. This means that the teacher urged the students to

options.B: turn to the next page of their book
options.C: sir the leaves in the compost pit
options.D: strike a balance between play and hardwork

explanation: "Turn over a new leaf" is an idiomatic expression meaning to change one's ways or improve one's behaviour.

text: Amina always flies off at a tangent when a serious matter is discussed. This means that Amina
explanation: The phrase "flies off at a tangent" means to go off-topic or to start talking about something unrelated, which is a form of digression.

text: You should take what he tells you with a pinch of salt. This means that you should

options.A: reject everything he says because he is a liar

explanation: To take something with a pinch of salt means to not completely believe something that you are told because it is unlikely to be true.

text: The bride was praised by her mother-in-law for her impeccable behaviour.
explanation: "Impeccable" means flawless or without fault, so "faultless" is the word that is nearest in meaning to "impeccable."

text: Ogene was not the least cowed by the bully's threats.
explanation: In this context, "cowed" means beingintimidatedor frightened into submission.

text: The dissidents held several clandestine meetings before the attack.
explanation: "Dissidents" are to individuals who oppose official policies or authorities, and "clandestine" means somethingsecretor hidden.

text: The Principal warned the final-year students about the consequences of procrastination.
explanation: "Procrastination" refers to the act of delaying or postponing something, so "delay" is the word nearest in meaning.

text: The incessant chatter of the pupils irritated the teacher.
explanation: "Incessant" means continuing without interruption, so "unceasing" is the word nearest in meaning.

text: With his cogent argument in favour of the proposal, he was able to check further opposition.
explanation: "Cogent" means persuasive or convincing, especially in terms of an argument or reasoning.

text: The professor's explanation of that point was quite lucid.
explanation: "Lucid" meansclear, easy to understand.

text: The foreman believed that with the augmented workforce, the construction job would take one more month to complete.
explanation: "Augmented" means increased orenlarged, so in this context, it refers to the workforce being made larger.

text: The children were warned not to be unduly inquisitive​​​​​​.
explanation: "inquisitive" means being excessivelycuriousor asking too many questions.

text: The accused vehemently denied the charges against him.
explanation: "Vehemently" means doing something with a strong feeling or force. So, "strongly" is the word that is nearest in meaning to "vehemently."

text: The man advised his children not to give.....to the temptations of the city.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"The man advised his children not to giveinto the temptations of the city."
"Give in" is a phrasal verb that means to yield or surrender to something.

text: Ebiere turned........... all the advances made by the men.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"Ebiereturned downall the advances made by the men."
"Turned down" is a phrasal verb that means to reject or refuse something.

text: Ada is .....to do that kind of thing.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"Ada ismuch too intelligentto do that kind of thing."
In this case, much too + [adjective] is the correct phrasing to express that Ada's intelligence is far beyond what would be required for such a task.

text: ......... were sent to the library by the English teacher.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"Udoh and Iwere sent to the library by the English teacher."
In English, when you are the subject of the sentence, "I" is used rather than "me" or "myself." Additionally, "I" should come after the other person's name (in this case, Udoh), as this is the correct order in formal writing.

text: The teachers ............ politics when I entered the staff room.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"The teacherswere discussingpolitics when I entered the staff room."
The correct form is "discussing" without "about" or "on," as "discuss" already means to talk about something. Also, the past continuous tense (were discussing) is used to show that the action of discussing politics was happening when a past action occurred (the action of entering into the staff room).

text: The quarrel between the two men soon resulted .... a fight.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"The quarrel between the two men soon resultedina fight."
The phrase "resulted in" is the correct prepositional phrase to express that the quarrel led to or caused a fight.

text: You're not too tired to continue, .........?
explanation:
The sentence would read:"You're not too tired to continue,are you?"
This is a tag question, and the correct form follows a negative statement ("You're nottoo tired") with a positive tag ("are you?").

text: The hunter, with his dogs,......... going into the forest.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"The hunter, with his dogs,was seengoing into the forest."
Here, "was seen" is correct because the subject of the sentence is "The hunter," which is singular. The phrase "with his dogs" does not change the singular nature of the subject.

text: Mother could not prepare the dish because there was....oil available.
explanation:
"Mother could not prepare the dish because there waslittleoil available."
In this context, "little" means that there was not enough oil to prepare the dish. You use "little" instead of "a little" when you want to emphasise the smallness in the quantity of something.

text: Because it had been raining heavily all morning...........people turned out to welcome the August visitor.
explanation:
The sentence would read:"Because it had been raining heavily all morning,fewpeople turned out to welcome the August visitor."
The word "few" is used to emphasise that only a small number of people attended due to the heavy rain. We use "a few" when we are not necessarily emphasising the smallness of the number but emphasising something else in the sentence.

text: Unfortunately, his plans to go abroad fell.........
explanation:
The phrasal verb "fell through" means that the plans did not succeed or were not completed as intended.
So, the sentence would read:"Unfortunately, his plans to go abroad fellthrough."

text: The man asked me ......
explanation:
When reporting an indirect question, the tense shifts back and no question mark is used. So, the correct form for an indirect question would be:
"The man asked mewho I was."

text: ''It is high time you....crying,'' the woman told her daughter gently.
explanation:
The phrase "It is high time" is followed by a verb in the past tense to show that an action should have already happened or is overdue. So the sentence would read:
"It is high time youstoppedcrying," the woman told her daughter gently."

text: He would rather resign ... part in such a dishonest deal.
explanation: The structure "rather + [base form of verb] + than + [base form of the verb]" is a common expression in English to show preference between two actions. Therefore, the correct construction is:  "He would rather resign than take part in such a dishonest deal"

text: Those who owe the company were urged to .......their debts.
explanation: To“Pay out”means to settle or discharge a debt.“Make good”typically means to fulfil a promise or repair something. It would only be accurate with the addition of the preposition "on" as in "make good on".“Run in”means to encounter someone.“Pay for”usually means to bear the cost of something. So, “pay out” is the most appropriate choice for this context.

text: .......home, his dead uncle's burial had already taken place.
explanation:
"When he got home, his dead uncle's burial had already taken place."
The burial had already taken place by the time he arrived. It doesn't imply that the burial happened as he arrived, but rather that the burial was completed before his arrival. So, "when he got home" is the most suitable choice.

text: Luck..........the robbers on that fateful day.
explanation:
The phrase "ran out on" is an idiomatic expression meaning that luck abandoned or failed the robbers on that fateful day.
The sentence should read:"Luckran out onthe robbers on that fateful day."

text: He never seemed to get it right..........
explanation:
The phrase "however hard he tried" is an adverbial phrase that means putting in effort but not achieving the desired outcome. The structure "however hard" is idiomatic and commonly used in English to express that regardless of the degree of effort, the result was still not satisfactory. Therefore, the complete sentence would be:
"He never seemed to get it right,however hard he tried."

text: The day that Musa's uncle died was the.....day of his life.
explanation: "Saddest" is the superlative form of the adjective "sad". The use of "most" before "saddest" is redundant. When using the superlative form, you don't need to add "most" because it already expresses the highest degree. Therefore, the correct and grammatically sound choice is option C, "saddest."

text: With his reading glasses on, he could see the words...............
explanation:
The phrase "much more clearly" is the grammatically correct order (Much more + [adverb]), as "much" modifies "more" and "more" modifies "clearly."
The sentence should read:"With his reading glasses on, he could see the wordsmuch more clearly."

text: Neither Obi nor Jumoke .......... present at the meeting.
explanation:
When two subjects are joined by "neither...nor," the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. In this case, "Jumoke" is singular, so the verb should be "was."
The sentence should read:"Neither Obi nor Jumokewaspresent at the meeting."

text: Hardly had the journey started..........the car engine developed a fault.
explanation: "Hardly...when" is a coordinating conjunction and both words are traditionally used side by side. So, the sentence would read: "Hardlyhad the journey startedwhenthe car engine developed a fault."

text: At the end of the year, Grandmother ..........with us for seven years.
explanation:
The future perfect tense "will have lived" would be appropriate for this sentence. The end of the year is still something in the future, so you have to relate this piece of information (the fact that grandmother will have lived with us for seven years) to the future event (the end of the year), using the future perfect tense.
At the end of the year, Grandmotherwill have livedwith us for seven years.

text: One of the robbers who snatched the car........been arrested by the police.
explanation:
One of the robbers who snatched the carhasbeen arrested by the police.
"Has" is used here because the subject "one of the robbers" is singular and the relative clause "who snatched the car" does not affect the verb form.

text: A student at the back of the class complained that he.......the teacher.
explanation: A student at the back of the class complained that hecould not hearthe teacher. "could" is the modal auxiliary that demonstrates ability. Using "could not" demonstrates the student's inability to hear the teacher.

text: The little boy could not move the heavy stone........he tried.
explanation: "However hard" shows that regardless of the level of effort or intensity of trying, the little boy was unable to move the heavy stone. So, the completed sentence reads: "The little boy could not move the heavy stonehoweverhard he tried."

text: The two girls have not been speaking.............since their quarrel.
explanation: The correct pronoun to use is "each other." Therefore, the complete and grammatically correct sentence is: "The two girls have not been speaking to each other since their quarrel." The reciprocal pronoun "each other" is used traditionally for two people while "one another" is used for three or more people.

text: We received........that the workers would soon go on strike.
explanation: The word "information" is uncountable, so it does not have a plural form. The correct sentence is:We receivedinformationthat the workers would soon go on strike.

text: He dabbles..........politics from time to time
explanation: The phrase "dabble in" means to take part in or engage in an activity superficially and without vested interest.

text: The government has set up a ....panel to investigate that fire incident
explanation: The government has set up afive-manpanel to investigate that fire incident. "Five-man" is a compound adjective that describes the panel, and compound adjectives use hyphens. The term refers to a panel consisting of five men.

text: The Students Week was rounded...with a dance
explanation:
To round offsomething means to bring it to a pleasing or satisfactory conclusion. Example:The meal was rounded off with a delicious dessert.
So, in the sentence:
The Students Week was rounded ___ with a dance
The most appropriate completion is:
The Students Week was roundedoffwith a dance.

text: After a while, we noticed that the unconscious accident victim was coming.........
explanation: The phrase "coming around" is an idiom that means that someone is regaining consciousness after being unconscious.

text: The factory workers refused to take the matter of their sacked colleagues lying............
explanation: The phrase "to take something lying down" is an idiom that means to accept something without protest or resistance. In the context of the sentence, the factory workers are not willing to accept the sacking of their colleagues passively or without taking action.

text: Seun accepted the conditions we gave him........for my liking.
explanation: Seun accepted the conditions we gave himmuch too quicklyfor my liking. "Much too + [adverb]" is the correct pattern for this expression. The sentence shows that Seun accepted the conditions too hastily.

text: The careless manager has caused his bank to .....millions of naira.
explanation:
The careless manager has caused his bank tolosemillions of naira.
Lose is the base form of the verb. The base form should be used in the to-infinitive form.

text: Both questions are alternatives; you answer......one.......the other.
explanation: The phrase "either...or" is used to show a choice between two alternatives. In this sentence, "Both questions are alternatives; you answereitheroneorthe other".

text: The sick man.........in bed for three months.
explanation: "lay" is the past tense of "lie" (to recline or be in a resting position). The completed sentence is: "The sick manlayin bed for three months"

text: Ogugua has always.........me as a good-mannered child.
explanation: In this sentence, the correct verb form to use is "struck" because past participle of the verb "strike". Coupled with the auxiliary verb "has", they make the past perfect form.

text: In question numbered 86 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: To "reproduce"  means for the human race to increase its numbers to survive under difficult conditions. Reproduction is the biological process needed to maintain population levels. text: In question numbered 87 above, choose the best option from letters A - D that best completes the gap.
explanation: "Rate" is the speed or frequency at which something happens. "Rate" is the most appropriate term here because it refers to a measurable quantity over time. The sentence would read: "Under these conditions, the human race needed to reproduce at a highratejust to keep in existence."
